field_edited_text.value:
!\

Traffic Needs



The following points are made by one or more of these reports:
1. All reports agree that a subway system is not feasible for Balti-

more. The report of the Committee on Mass Transportation
summarizes this common viewpoint as follows: ‘“Baltimore is far
from an ideal city for the building of subways in which trains of
cars are operated on fixed ballasted rails. The streets are quite
narrow; there are a number of hills, which would call for deep
subway tunnels and long steps, escalators or elevators for reaching
the ground surface; much rock would be encountered in the north-
ern and northwestern areas of the City, and the spokes-of-a-wheel
passenger movement pattern make it difficult to contemplate that
subways costing $250,000,000 or more are economically, politically
or physically justified when comparison is made with other types
of rapid transit which may be available.”

. All reports agree that with respect to monorails many engineering

problems remain to be solved and that no present reliance can be
placed upon this system. The Committee on Mass Transportation
adds this comment: ‘“The prospect of such overhead construction
in our Baltimore streets, approaching as it will an elevated rail
system in the amount of light and air intercepted and the amount
of noise emitted is not a happy one.”

. The Committee on Mass Transportation suggests that existing

railroad lines might be converted to rapid transit use. Mr. Barnes
feels that this proposal is not feasible, in part because of sparse
development along these rights-of-way and in part because com-
muters would have to be brought to the railroad lines by bus or
by auto. Such “divided trips” would, he feels, discourage patron-
age. The Regional Planning Council study endeavors to explore
in some detail the possibility of utilizing existing rail lines for

17

rapid transit purposes. It suggests that three rail rapid transit
lines could extend out from the center of the City to the north-
east, the north, and the northwest. A southern terminal is pro-
posed at Charles Center by means of a tunnel from the Calvert
Street Station. An analysis was made of the population in the
districts served, the extent to which this population might be
employed in the central business district, and the extent to which
the proposed lines might be utilized. It is estimated that trip-to-
work patronage in 1980 might total 15,000, of which, however,
only 10,000 would represent a shift from private automobiles.
The remaining 5,000 would, in the absence of the proposed rapid
transit, be using buses.

All discussion of rail rapid transit is based upon a system designed
to service downtown and which would be only of incidental benefit
to other employment areas. While the reports do not so state,
this emphasis on downtown clearly stems from the fact that there
are no other traffic generators in the metropolitan area, now or
foreseeable, of sufficient size, compactness, or ability to develop
non-rush hour traffic to support any type of rail rapid transit
system without exorbitant subsidy.

With respect to buses the Committee on Mass Transportation
states that: ‘“Mass transportation free-wheel buses (not trackless
trolleys or rail facilities under any circumstances) must have free
access on, along and off such [expressways]. Once on the [ex-
pressway] such buses shall maintain the speed of other vehicles
until they reach their point of exit. Good entry and egress, of
course, must be provided for the buses and other free-wheeled
vehicles.” Mr. Barnes in his reports carries this viewpoint one
step further by stating that express buses qtilizing expressways
